inscription:
by Shōbaitei Kiraku in Osaka: Kagi no oto/ kutsuwa ni nitaru/ tsure zeni wa/ ashige ni aranu/ Yoshida komahiki (Keys rattle in my wallet/ jangling against the coins that are tied together./ Although tied-up coins look like a horse\'s bit,/ they are not attached to a roan horse/ but to the horse coins made in Yoshida.); Hana no ka ni/ kaze no fukucha no/ umeboshi no/ shiwashiwa samuki/ haru no setsubun (The wind brings the scent of plum blossoms,/ ruffling the surface of the lucky tea/ flavored with a dried plum./ Although it is still a little cold,/ today is the beginning of spring!)

by Tōryūkan Michimori in Edo: Iyamashi ni/ shiawase Yoshida no / komahiki no/ mago mo mouke shi/ haru no fukucha zo (I am happier than ever./ As the Yoshida coin brings happiness/ my mago (horse handler) brings me mago (a grand child)./ What a happy spring day!/ Let\'s celebrate with flavored lucky tea.)

by Shūchōdō Monoyana: Uguisu no/ ne ni sasoware tsu/ umega ka wo/ kagitsuke te kuru/ haru no komadori (Following the voice/ of a bush warbler,/ here comes a robin/ attracted by the scent/ of a blooming plum.)

by Yomo-utagaki Magao: Ehō yori/ mazy niiharu no/ kagibukuro/ hairu wa yorozu/ Yoshida komahiki (From an auspicious direction/ spring comes to enrich even my wallet./ But all that\'s getting in there/ are Yoshida horse coins.)
medium: Woodblock print (surimono); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From A Set of Horses (Uma zukushi 馬盡)
signed: Fusenkyo Iitsu hitsu 不染居為一筆
title: Leading-a-Horse Money
